posts.name: Abdullah Khaled
posts.cooked:
Our team has historically struggled with PID tuning, which has taken our programmers several days to get even basic subsystems dialed in. Despite this, we've had varying success; teams like [1678] and [9483] have shown more efficiency.  

I was wondering if anyone knows of resources that can help us understand both the concepts and practical applications of PID tuning. Resources might include books, videos, articles, or even examples of how others have tuned their systems.  

Would you happen to know any good places to look for such information?

link_counts.title: Advanced Controls Introduction — FIRST Robotics Competition documentation

posts.name: Tim Winters
posts.cooked: A big factor is mechanical robustness. If your mechanism has a lot of slop or backlash, you're gonna have a tough time tuning no matter what. There’s no positional feedforward for either the shoulder or the elbow. Both are motion magic control modes from CTRE. There is a kV value for the velocity feedforward built into motion magic. The elbow is small enough that you don’t need any elaborate control scheme to achieve the accuracy required for the application. The shoulder was counterbalanced with a pair of gas springs that made the shoulder pivot weight neutral through its working range of motion. Gas springs also act as a damper.

link_counts.title: Team 2056 OP Robotics Technical Binder Release

posts.cooked: You may want to pay attention to CD Chief Delphi. I am going to announce a few useful tools that you may want to use in the future that will help with tuning and development. We are working on completing them more before we open it up.

posts.name: Sam Carlberg
posts.cooked:
The text is extremely important and should be presented cleanly. Here is the cleaned version:

Squirre1Master mentions that given the motor's speed, torque, and load, what values would be good?. SysID does exactly this based on measurements taken of your system but requires good data logging. You can also calculate PD values yourself if you have a very good model of the system’s motor intrinsics and mass/moment of inertia usually derived from a detailed CAD model. Seconding Tim that PIDF control cannot compensate for slop and backlash. You need to ensure that belts and chains are properly tensioned and possibly shims on gears/sprockets/pulleys to remove slop between them and their axles.

posts.name: Carter Ryba
posts.cooked: Does nstrike have some super secret PID tuning automator in this works :eyes:

Not sure what could be taking an entire day to tune a subsystem, but if it helps, my general procedure is:

Start with a comically small P (like 0.00001). Increase by orders of magnitude till you see any movement at all. Use your judgement to increase P until it slightly overshoots (don’t increase by orders of magnitude probably, and just be somewhat conservative). Decrease P till it doesn’t overshhoot/you get the desired results. Ignore I and D.

To be clear, this is for straight PID control, not motion profiles. It should only take like a maximum of 12 deploys to tune, which is not that long given that you’re only changing one number per deploy. Unless compilation takes really long, idk because my team uses Python. If you don’t trust me, I think there’s at least one powerhouse team that uses this approach.

Remember that kp, ki, kd have units. If you’ve told your spiking max that it’s in radians, then kp’s units are (duty cycle)/(radian).

In terms of media explaining PID, I liked this video: [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=wkfEZmsQqiA](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=wkfEZmsQqiA)  
For feedforwards, I liked this article: [Introduction to DC Motor Feedforward — FIRST Robotics Competition documentation](https://docs/wpilib.org/en/stable/docs/software/advanced-controls/introduction/introduction-to-feedforward.html#introduction-to-dc-motor-feedforward)  

PIDF took a long period of marinating in my mind to understand it fully so your programmers may need some time as well. That said, the above instructions work well enough that they’re probably usable before the concepts have marinated fully.

For examples, I say just try it yourself with the above instructions.  

In terms of guesstimation, don’t do it. It doesn’t really help, and is not as easy/helpful as the above instructions.

link_counts.title: Introduction to DC Motor Feedforward — FIRST Robotics Competition documentation

posts.name: Tim Winters
posts.cooked:
D is still useful in FIRST Robotics Competition.  

I like to start with a P value that gives full motor output for approximately half the range of travel and then adjust as needed. For instance, if tuning an elevator with a 48-inch travel range, half is 24 inches, so solving 12 equals kp times 24 results in kp being 0.5. If the measurement is in meters, the equation becomes 12 equals kp times 0.6, leading to a kp of 20.  

Nowadays, using rotations of the output stage as the measurement is recommended but the concept remains the same. For a mechanism with 180 degrees of motion (or 0.5 rotations), solving 12 equals kp times 0.25 yields a kp of 48.

ArchdukeTim mentions that D is still useful in FIRST Robotics Competition. He notes that he hasn’t noticed much difference from using D himself but points out that teams like 2659 report having great, snappy controls.

posts.name: Kabir
posts.cooked: In my opinion, needing a deploy for tuning results in a lot of lost time (although I haven’t worked with robotpy before so I don’t know how fast deploys are with it). If you’re tuning PID controllers running on a motor controller, it’s usually faster to use that vendor’s configuration app to change the PID values. Otherwise you can try reading values from a dashboard.

You don’t need to deploy every time if you use WPILib’s PIDController—you can publish it to NetworkTables and edit the gains from your dashboard; just make sure to include them in the code whenever you re-deploy.

posts.name: Jimmy McCosker
posts.cooked: This season, we followed a guide in the linked post from team 3255 to tune our elevator, and it worked well. We tune our subsystems in a unique way, and it’s been effective! I highly recommend using Phoenix Tuner for this, as it’s fast and helps change motor constants. Set all PID constants to 0, command the elevator to move, adjust it manually, and…

posts.name: Jeffrey Davis
posts.cooked: When constructing the system, consider using Recal or a comparable tool to achieve the fastest performance. This will grant you powerful capabilities beneficial across various applications and tasks. Moving forward, you may skip the extremely low p-value and begin at .01 (1%), though typically starting at around 5-7% is sufficient for most systems. Adjusting your approach to move more slowly is entirely optional. The key is selecting the appropriate gear ratios between speed and power, which simplifies fine-tuning PID values significantly.

posts.cooked: Our process for tuning our elevator this year involved implementing Motion Profiled, Feedforward, and Feedback Control within WPILib classes. To determine feedforward gains, we followed specific steps: identifying the minimum and maximum voltages associated with elevator movement to calculate kG and kS. We utilized AdvantageScope for data visualization. Additionally, we considered suggestions regarding efficient deployment strategies and explored the DogLog tunable system for potential future use.

link_counts.title: Tuning a Vertical Elevator with Motion Profiling — FIRST Robotics Competition documentation

posts.name: Katie Widen
posts.cooked: If you want to practice writing and tuning PID loops from scratch, I recommend this simulator. It’s not designed for FIRST Robotics Competition and uses JavaScript, but it gamifies the process with increasing levels of difficulty. This will only work for levels with blocks and distance but you get the idea. var p_val; var i_val = 0; var prev_p = 0; var d_val; /*you change these*/ var kP = 1; var kI = 0; var kD = 0; function controlFunction(block) { /*error: distance from setpoint, in this case the setpoint is 0*/ p_val = 0-block.x; /*accumulated error*/ i_val += block.x; /*change in error*/ d_val = p_val - prev_p; return kP*p_val + kI*i_val + kD*d_val; } Something like this website can be helpful to practice tuning the PID constants but isn’t terribly intuitive.

posts.name: Eli Barnett
posts.cooked: Curious as to what some of those might be? The only one that's mine to announce is a LQR plugin for ReCalc that does the same thing as SysId Theoretical Mode. So, ReCalc will be able to provide optimal P and D gains for your mechanism. (If you specify all the parameters correctly…) There's active discussion of all this stuff on the FRC Discord, for what it's worth.

posts.name: Dan
posts.cooked:
Slightly tangential to your issue but worth noting, ensuring account for feed-forward mechanisms and motion profiling can enhance performance. A foundational understanding here can yield substantial benefits with minimal time investment compared to in-depth PID analysis. PID math is tailored for specific scenarios and, while effective, can underperform if not properly applied.

Conventional practice involved extensive effort in PID tuning until we discovered an efficient approach. Now, minimal tuning is needed—utilizing precomputed feed-forward values alongside defined motion profiles stabilizes and minimizes system error. As the situation evolved, adjustments were confined to refining these feed-forward settings, leaving the PID loop untouched. This streamlined method has proven far more rewarding.
